section.introduction: Surah Ta-Ha is the twentieth surah of the Quran, revealed in Makkah. It is named after the mysterious letters "Ta" and "Ha" that appear at the beginning of the surah. It primarily focuses on the story of the Prophet Moses (Musa), his confrontations with Pharaoh, and the signs of divine power manifested through these events. The surah also addresses themes of guidance, faith, and perseverance, reiterating the principles of prophecy and revelation. Ta-Ha highlights Allah's mercy for those who obey His commandments and emphasizes the importance of remaining steadfast in faith despite difficulties.
section.title: The Message of Moses

item.title: The Call of Moses
item.description: The surah begins with the call of Moses by Allah. Moses is chosen to free the Israelites from Pharaoh's oppression. The dialogue between Allah and Moses is detailed, showing the signs and miracles given to Moses to convince Pharaoh.

item.title: The Miracle of the Staff
item.description: The surah describes the miracle of Moses' staff turning into a serpent. This miracle, along with other signs, is intended to demonstrate divine power and persuade Pharaoh to release the Israelites.

item.title: Opposition and Punishment
item.description: The surah describes Pharaoh's opposition and his attempts to deny the divine signs. It also addresses the consequences of his arrogance and refusal to believe in Allah.

item.title: The Punishment of Pharaoh
item.description: The final fate of Pharaoh and his army is mentioned, highlighting divine justice in response to their oppression and rejection of God's signs.

item.title: Crossing the Red Sea
item.description: The surah recounts the miraculous crossing of the Red Sea by the Israelites and the destruction of Pharaoh and his army. This event is presented as a sign of Allah's power and protection.

item.title: The Worship of the Golden Calf
item.description: It also addresses the deviation of the Israelites after leaving Egypt, particularly their worship of the golden calf and the consequences of this idolatry.

item.title: Dialogue and Preaching
item.description: The surah includes the dialogue between Moses and Allah, highlighting the lessons of patience, faith, and responsibility in fulfilling the prophetic mission.

item.title: The Importance of Guidance
item.description: It emphasizes the importance of following divine guidance and staying true to Allah's teachings.

item.title: Moral Behavior
item.description: The surah offers guidance on moral and ethical behavior, emphasizing the importance of faith, patience, and submission to divine will.

item.title: Individual Responsibility
item.description: It stresses individual responsibility in faith and actions, and the importance of repentance and returning to Allah.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Anbiya (The Prophets) is the twenty-first surah of the Quran, revealed in Makkah. It deals with the stories of several prophets, including Ibrahim (Abraham), Musa (Moses), and Dawud (David), to illustrate lessons of faith, patience, and perseverance. The surah highlights the trials these prophets faced and how they guided their communities despite obstacles. Al-Anbiya emphasizes the importance of believing in Allah and His messengers, while warning of the consequences of rejecting divine signs. It also reminds of Allah’s mercy and justice, as well as the necessity of following the path of righteousness.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Hajj (The Pilgrimage) is the twenty-second surah of the Quran, revealed in Medina. It addresses the theme of the pilgrimage to Mecca (Hajj) and its associated rites, as well as the spiritual and moral significances of this act of devotion. The surah also discusses principles of faith, justice, and the struggle against injustice and disbelief. It highlights the importance of Hajj as a symbol of unity and submission to Allah, while emphasizing the values of piety, purity, and sincerity in religious practice. Al-Hajj reminds believers of Allah's greatness and the importance of submission to His commandments.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Mu’minun (The Believers) is the twenty-third surah of the Quran, revealed in Makkah. It focuses on the characteristics of true believers and the qualities that distinguish them, such as patience, prayer, and modesty. The surah also describes the rewards awaiting the pious believers and the consequences for those who reject faith. It includes narratives of the prophets to illustrate how true believers faced trials and persevered in their faith. Al-Mu’minun emphasizes the importance of sincere faith, moral integrity, and commitment to Allah's teachings.
section.title: The Believers

item.title: Definition of Believers
item.description: Believers are defined as those who have faith in Allah, His messengers, and divine revelation. They accept divine guidance and strive to live in accordance with Islamic teachings.

item.title: Qualities of Believers
item.description: Believers are characterized by their sincerity, devotion, patience, and perseverance in faith. They are also honest, just, and merciful towards others.

item.title: Religious Practices
item.description: Believers engage in religious practices such as prayer, fasting, zakat (charity), and pilgrimage (Hajj). These practices strengthen their faith and their relationship with Allah.

item.title: Ethical Behavior
item.description: Believers adhere to strict ethical principles, including justice, truth, and compassion. They avoid harmful actions and seek to promote well-being and justice in society.

item.title: Family Relations
item.description: Believers are encouraged to maintain respectful and loving family relationships. They honor their parents, support their relatives, and maintain strong family ties.

item.title: Social Relations
item.description: Believers interact with others in a respectful and compassionate manner. They are friendly, tolerant, and seek to help others in need.

item.title: Spiritual Responsibility
item.description: Believers have the responsibility to cultivate their faith, practice religion correctly, and strive for piety. They are also responsible for the religious education of their children and community.

item.title: Social Responsibility
item.description: Believers have the responsibility to contribute positively to society, promote social well-being, and participate in actions that benefit the community.

item.description: Believers are called to follow high ethical and moral principles based on Islamic teachings. This includes justice, truth, patience, and compassion towards others.

section.introduction: Surah An-Nur (The Light) is the twenty-fourth surah of the Quran, revealed in Medina. It addresses themes related to morality, family, and social life, emphasizing guidelines on proper conduct, relationships between men and women, and rules of decency. An-Nur also deals with spiritual light, symbolizing the divine guidance that illuminates the path of the believers. The surah contains important verses on modesty, accusations of false morality, and social ethics, while highlighting the necessity of adhering to divine laws to lead a just and balanced life.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Furqan (The Criterion) is the twenty-fifth surah of the Quran, revealed in Mecca. It focuses on the signs of divine revelation and the importance of discerning truth from falsehood. The term "Al-Furqan" means "the Criterion," referring to the ability to distinguish between truth and error. The surah addresses the characteristics of true believers, critiques of disbelievers, and evidence of Allah's existence and power through creation. It emphasizes the believers' responsibility to follow Allah's teachings and lead a life in accordance with divine guidance.
section.title: Context

item.title: Period of Revelation
item.description: Al-Furqan is a Meccan surah revealed during a time when early Muslims faced significant persecution.

item.title: Objective
item.description: It aims to strengthen the faith of believers by addressing the critiques of polytheists and presenting arguments for the truthfulness of the prophetic message.

item.title: Refutation of Accusations
item.description: The Meccan polytheists accused the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) of inventing the Quran. The surah responds to these accusations by affirming that the Quran is a divine revelation.

item.title: Critique of Idols
item.description: The surah criticizes idol worship by highlighting their inability to create or help.

item.title: The Parable of Truth and Falsehood
item.description: Al-Furqan uses parables to show how truth will ultimately prevail over falsehood.

item.title: The Importance of Guidance
item.description: The Quran is presented as guidance for those willing to accept the truth.

item.title: The Quran as a Criterion
item.description: Al-Furqan emphasizes that the Quran is the criterion for distinguishing between good and evil.

item.title: The Transience of Worldly Life
item.description: The surah reminds that worldly life is temporary and that the Day of Judgment is inevitable.

item.title: Refutation of False Gods
item.description: It refutes the idea that idols or false gods can be of any benefit.

item.title: Characteristics of True Believers
item.description: Toward the end of the surah, the characteristics of true believers are described, including their humility, patience, and complete submission to Allah.

section.introduction: Surah Ash-Shu'ara (The Poets) is the twenty-sixth surah of the Quran, revealed in Mecca. It focuses on the stories of the prophets and their challenges faced with the people who rejected their messages. The name "Ash-Shu'ara" refers to poets, highlighting the importance of poetry and oratory in pre-Islamic culture. The surah addresses themes of revelation, rejection of prophets, and the consequences for those who persist in disbelief. It emphasizes the perseverance of the prophets and divine truth, while calling on believers to remain steadfast in their faith despite adversities.

section.introduction: Surah An-Naml (The Ants) is the twenty-seventh surah of the Quran, revealed in Mecca. It is named after the story of the ant speaking to Prophet Solomon (Sulayman). The surah addresses the stories of prophets, particularly Solomon, and their communities, illustrating divine power and wisdom. It highlights the signs of creation, the miracles of the prophets, and lessons of faith and gratitude. An-Naml emphasizes the importance of recognizing God's signs, accepting divine guidance, and turning away from disbelief and rejection of prophetic messages.

item.title: Divine Revelation
item.description: The surah begins by highlighting the importance of the Quran as a divine revelation that guides believers towards the truth.

item.title: Solomon and the Ants
item.description: One of the most famous stories in this surah is about Prophet Solomon, known for his wisdom and power. He is described as having an army composed of men, jinn, and birds, and being able to understand the language of animals. As he passes with his army, he hears an ant warning other ants to take cover to avoid being crushed. Solomon smiles at the ant's words and thanks God for this blessing.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Qasas (The Stories) is the twenty-eighth surah of the Quran, revealed in Makkah. It is named for the detailed narratives it contains, including that of Prophet Moses (Musa) and his confrontation with Pharaoh. The surah addresses themes of divine guidance, liberation of the oppressed, and justice. It highlights the trials faced by Moses and the signs of Allah's power manifested through these events. Al-Qasas also emphasizes the importance of faith and patience, while reminding that divine truth always prevails, even in the face of tyranny and injustice.
section.title: Context

item.title: Period of Revelation
item.description: The surah The Stories is a Meccan surah revealed after Surah Al-Ankabut and before Surah An-Naml. It was revealed during a period when the early Muslims were facing significant challenges and persecution.

item.title: Objective
item.description: It aims to strengthen the faith of believers by highlighting the stories of previous prophets and their struggles, to show that persecution and difficulties are common aspects of prophetic missions.

item.title: The Story of Moses
item.description: The surah begins with the detailed story of Moses, from his birth to his prophetic mission, including his upbringing in Egypt and his conflict with Pharaoh.

item.title: The Story of Qarun
item.description: It also describes Qarun’s wealth and arrogance, followed by his downfall when Allah punished him for his pride and rejection of divine teachings.

item.title: The Story of the Reward for Believers
item.description: The surah emphasizes the rewards given to believers who persist in faith despite trials, and how divine justice manifests in their lives.

item.title: The Persistence of Prophets
item.description: The stories of the prophets show their persistence in their divine mission despite obstacles and persecution.

item.title: Divine Justice
item.description: The surah highlights divine justice that rewards believers and punishes the unjust.

item.title: Leadership and Arrogance
item.description: The story of Qarun illustrates how arrogance and pride lead to destruction, while humility and faith are rewarded.

item.title: Divine Guidance
item.description: The narratives show how Allah guides His messengers and their communities through trials.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Ankabut (The Spider) is the twenty-ninth surah of the Quran, revealed in Makkah. It is named after the story of the spider, used as a metaphor to illustrate the fragility of false beliefs and the importance of true faith. The surah deals with themes of faith, trials of the believers, and the challenges faced by the prophets. It recounts the stories of several prophets, such as Noah, Abraham, and Lot, and highlights lessons of patience and perseverance. Al-Ankabut emphasizes that sincere faith is essential to overcome difficulties and that divine guidance is always available to those who seek it.
section.title: Context

item.title: Test and Patience
item.description: The surah begins by affirming that believers will be tested to gauge the sincerity of their faith. It emphasizes that true faith is demonstrated through patience and perseverance in the face of difficulties.

item.title: Stories of the Prophets
item.description: The trials are presented as a means for God to distinguish sincere believers from hypocrites. Those who remain steadfast in their faith despite trials are promised divine reward.

item.title: Stories of the Prophets
item.description: The surah mentions the narratives of several prophets, including Noah (Nuh), Abraham (Ibrahim), Lot (Lut), Shuayb (Jethro), and Moses (Musa). These stories show how each prophet faced opposition and trials while calling people to worship God and reject polytheism.

item.title: Abraham and Lot
item.description: The story of Abraham is discussed, highlighting his rejection of idols and his call to the oneness of God. The people of Lot are mentioned to show the consequences of sin and rejection of the divine message.

item.title: Punishment of the Unjust
item.description: The surah warns against the consequences of rejecting the divine message and sin. The peoples who refused the prophets and persisted in injustice were destroyed by divine punishment.

item.title: The Spider's Example
item.description: Verse 41 compares those who take other protectors besides God to the spider that weaves a house. This house is fragile and cannot protect against dangers, just as false protectors cannot shield against divine punishment.

item.title: Polytheism vs. Monotheism
item.description: The surah harshly criticizes polytheism, asserting that idols and false gods are powerless and can neither harm nor protect. It calls people to worship God alone, who is the true protector and the only one worthy of worship.

item.title: Reminder of Resurrection
item.description: The surah also reminds of the Day of Resurrection, where each person will be judged according to their actions. The disbelievers and those who turn away from God will be punished, while the believers will be rewarded.

item.title: Exhortation to Patience
item.description: Believers are encouraged to remain steadfast in their faith, to persevere in good deeds, and to be patient in the face of adversities. The reward for patience and sincere faith is assured.

item.title: False Security of the Unjust
item.description: Those who feel secure by following their desires or relying on idols are warned that their end will be tragic, as true security lies only in faith in God.

item.title: Test of Faith
item.description: Verses 1-11: The importance of trials to test the sincerity of the faith of believers.

item.title: Prophet Stories

section.introduction: Surah Ar-Rum (The Romans) is the thirtieth surah of the Quran, revealed in Mecca. It is named after the Byzantines (Romans) mentioned at the beginning of the surah. The surah addresses themes such as the prophecy of the Byzantines' victory, signs of God in creation, resurrection and the Last Judgment, the oneness of God, and the fluctuations of human life. It emphasizes the truthfulness of the divine message through fulfilled prophecies and invites reflection on nature and faith.

section.introduction: Surah Luqman is the 31st surah of the Quran, consisting of 34 verses. It is named after Luqman, a wise man known for his advice and wisdom, whom God mentions in this surah. The surah addresses themes such as wisdom, the importance of gratitude towards God, and respect for parents. Luqman gives advice to his son on faith, moral behavior, and virtuous conduct in life. The surah also emphasizes the importance of knowledge, patience, and justice in the lives of believers.

It addresses essential themes such as the creation of man, resurrection, the Day of Judgment, the reward for believers, and the punishment for disbelievers. The surah begins with an affirmation of the divine revelation of the Quran and highlights the signs of creation that prove God's existence and power. It invites believers to prostrate before God in acknowledgment of His majesty and mercy. The surah also discusses the blessings awaiting the righteous and warns against the consequences of disbelief. It calls for reflection on the reality of life after death and living a life of faith and devotion to God.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Ahzab (The Confederates) is the 33rd surah of the Quran, consisting of 73 verses. It is named after the historical event of the Battle of the Confederates (or Battle of the Trench), where enemy tribes allied to attack Medina. This surah addresses themes such as faith, loyalty to Prophet Muhammad, social justice, and family and community rules. It highlights the importance of obedience to God and the Messenger, while reminding of essential moral values for the Muslim society. It was revealed to guide believers in times of crisis and to strengthen their unity in the face of adversity.

section.introduction: Surah Saba (Sheba) is the 34th surah of the Quran, consisting of 54 verses. This surah deals with the omnipotence of God, resurrection, the Last Judgment, and the resulting reward or punishment. It highlights the signs of God in the universe and invites people to recognize and submit to His will. It also recounts the stories of the prophets David and Solomon, emphasizing their benefits and justice as servants of God.

The surah also reminds of the consequences of ingratitude and disobedience while encouraging believers to be patient and persevering in faith. item.title: Moral and Spiritual Lessons
item.description: Verses 31-35: Lessons of patience, perseverance, faith, and loyalty.

item.title: Divine Victory
item.description: The surah celebrates the divine victory at the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah and Allah’s favor.

item.title: Believers’ Traits
item.description: It describes the traits of true believers and their fidelity.

item.title: Relations with Non-Believers
item.description: It discusses the just treatment of non-believers and responses to hostility.

item.title: Divine Promises
item.description: It promises rewards for believers and warns disbelievers.

item.title: Spiritual Lessons
item.description: The surah teaches patience, perseverance, and the importance of loyalty to Allah and the Prophet.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Hujurāt (The Rooms) is the 49th surah of the Qur'an, consisting of 18 verses. It addresses important themes such as moral behavior, mutual respect, and communal living. The surah provides guidelines on how to treat others with respect, avoid conflicts and divisions, and maintain harmonious relationships among members of the Muslim community. It emphasizes the need for modesty, respecting others' privacy, and avoiding suspicions and slanders. The surah also highlights the importance of justice and fairness in social interactions.
section.title: Respect and Social Etiquette

item.title: Respect for the Prophet
item.description: The surah begins with directives on respecting the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), warning against rushing in the presence of the Prophet and the importance of showing him respect.

item.title: Social Etiquette
item.description: It establishes principles of social etiquette and respect in interactions among members of the Muslim community.

item.title: Community Unity
item.description: The surah emphasizes the importance of unity and brotherhood among believers, discouraging unnecessary division and conflicts.

item.title: Brotherhood
item.description: It highlights the need to treat each believer with respect and avoid behaviors that harm social cohesion.

item.title: Avoiding Prejudices
item.description: The surah addresses prejudices and hasty judgments, advising against making assumptions about others without evidence.

item.title: Verification of Information
item.description: It encourages verifying information before spreading it and condemns the spreading of rumors.

item.title: Conflict Resolution
item.description: The surah provides advice on resolving conflicts between believers in a fair and just manner.

item.title: Reconciliation
item.description: It emphasizes the importance of reconciliation and mediation to restore harmony in the community.

item.title: Ethical Behavior
item.description: The surah offers guidance on ethical and moral behavior, emphasizing honesty, justice, and kindness.

item.title: Individual Responsibility
item.description: It reminds believers of their individual responsibility in maintaining morality and ethics in their social interactions.

item.title: Respect and Social Etiquette
item.description: Verses 1-5: Guidelines on respecting the Prophet, social etiquette, and caution in interactions.

item.title: Unity and Brotherhood
item.description: Verses 6-11: Importance of unity and brotherhood among believers, respectful treatment of others, and avoiding conflicts.

item.title: Prejudices and Judgments
item.description: Verses 12-14: Avoiding prejudices, verifying information, and condemning rumors.

item.title: Reconciliation and Conflict Resolution
item.description: Verses 15-19: Advice on conflict resolution and the importance of reconciliation.

item.title: Ethical and Moral Principles
item.description: Verses 20-24: Ethical behavior, individual responsibility, and the importance of morality.

item.title: Respect for the Prophet
item.description: The surah emphasizes respect for the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and proper social etiquette.

item.title: Unity and Brotherhood
item.description: It highlights the necessity of maintaining unity and brotherhood among believers.

item.title: Prejudices and Judgments
item.description: The surah advises against prejudices and encourages verification of information.

item.title: Reconciliation
item.description: It provides guidance on conflict resolution and reconciliation.

item.title: Ethical Principles
item.description: The surah highlights the ethical and moral principles to be followed in social interactions.

section.introduction: Surah Qāf is the 50th surah of the Quran, consisting of 45 verses. It is named after the Arabic letter "Qāf" that appears at the beginning of the surah. This surah addresses themes of resurrection, the Day of Judgment, and the truthfulness of the prophetic message. It mentions signs of God in creation and the stories of past prophets, such as Moses and the people who rejected divine truth. The surah highlights God's power, the reality of life after death, and the consequences for the disbelievers. It serves as a reminder for believers to remain steadfast in their faith and accept divine signs.
section.title: Revelation and Prophecy

item.title: Truth of Revelation
item.description: The surah begins with the affirmation of the truth of the Quran and the prophetic mission. It emphasizes that the Quran is a divine revelation, confirming previous revelations.

item.title: Reactions of the Disbelievers
item.description: It addresses the reactions of disbelievers who reject revelation and prophecy despite the evident signs of divine truth.

item.title: Resurrection of the Dead
item.description: The surah discusses the theme of resurrection, explaining that the dead will be resurrected on the Day of Judgment. It affirms that resurrection is an inevitable reality.

item.title: Day of Judgment
item.description: It describes the events of the Day of Judgment, emphasizing that people's actions will be judged with justice and fairness.

item.title: Objections of the Disbelievers
item.description: The surah responds to the objections of disbelievers who doubt resurrection and Judgment. It explains why these doubts are unfounded and highlights Allah's power.

item.title: Examples of the Prophets
item.description: The surah mentions the stories of past prophets, such as Noah, 'Ād, and Thamūd. These narratives serve to illustrate the truthfulness of prophetic messages and the consequences of disbelief.

item.title: Reflection on Divine Signs
item.description: The surah encourages people to reflect on God's signs in nature and history to recognize His power and creation.

item.title: Responsibility and Retribution
item.description: It reminds believers of their responsibility in their actions and the divine retribution that awaits them.

item.title: Revelation and Prophecy
item.description: Verses 1-10: Affirmation of the truth of the Quran, reaction of disbelievers, and responses to objections.

item.title: Resurrection and Judgment
item.description: Verses 11-30: Description of resurrection, the Day of Judgment, and the consequences for believers and disbelievers.

item.title: Reactions and Objections
item.description: Verses 31-38: Responses to objections regarding resurrection and Judgment, and affirmation of Allah's power.

item.title: Stories of the Prophets
item.description: Verses 39-45: Narratives of past prophets and the lessons derived from their stories.

item.title: Moral and Spiritual Lessons
item.description: Verses 46-50: Reflection on divine signs, individual responsibility, and divine retribution.

item.title: Truth of the Quran
item.description: The surah affirms the truth of the Quran and the prophetic mission.

item.title: Resurrection
item.description: It discusses the resurrection of the dead and the events of the Day of Judgment.

item.title: Reactions of the Disbelievers
item.description: The surah addresses the objections of disbelievers concerning resurrection.

item.title: Stories of the Prophets
item.description: The stories of the prophets illustrate the truthfulness of prophetic messages.

item.title: Moral Lessons
item.description: The surah encourages reflection on divine signs and reminds of individual responsibility and divine retribution.

section.introduction: Surah Adh-Dhariyat (The Scattering Winds) is the 51st surah of the Quran, consisting of 60 verses. It is named after the "dhariyat" or "scattering winds" mentioned in the first verse, symbolizing signs of Allah in nature. The surah addresses themes such as the oneness of Allah, resurrection, and the consequences of rejecting the divine message. It narrates the stories of the prophets Abraham and Lot, highlighting the trials they faced and the lessons derived from their stories. The surah emphasizes the truth of life after death and judgment, and encourages believers to remain steadfast and perseverant.
section.title: Power of Allah and Signs in Creation

item.title: The Winds as Signs
item.description: The surah begins by mentioning the winds that scatter, symbolizing Allah's power in creation and nature. These natural phenomena are signs for those who reflect.

item.title: The Creation and the Universe
item.description: It highlights the grandeur of the universe and the harmony of creation, encouraging humanity to recognize Allah’s power through these signs.

item.title: Reality of Resurrection
item.description: The surah insists on the reality of resurrection, despite the skepticism of disbelievers. It affirms that the dead will be resurrected to be judged.

item.title: Day of Judgment
item.description: It describes the Day of Judgment, when each person will be rewarded or punished based on their actions.

item.title: Prophet Stories
item.description: The surah narrates the stories of prophets Abraham, Moses, Noah, and others. These stories show the continuity of the divine message through the ages and the consequences of disbelief.

item.title: Destruction of Disbelieving Nations
item.description: It highlights the nations that were destroyed due to their rejection of the prophets and their disbelief.

item.title: Call to Faith
item.description: The surah calls people to believe in Allah, follow the teachings of the prophets, and prepare for the Hereafter.

item.title: Rewards for the Righteous
item.description: It describes the rewards awaiting the righteous in Paradise, in contrast to the punishments for disbelievers.

item.title: Power of Allah and Signs
item.description: Verses 1-23: The winds and other signs in nature, the creation of the universe, and cosmic harmony as evidence of Allah's power.

item.title: Resurrection and Judgment
item.description: Verses 24-46: Affirmation of resurrection and description of the Day of Judgment, with a warning against skepticism.

item.title: Stories of the Prophets
item.description: Verses 47-60: Stories of Abraham, Moses, Noah, and other prophets, highlighting the divine message and the consequences of rejection.

item.title: Ethics and Spirituality
item.description: Verses 61-60: Call to faith, description of rewards for the righteous, and exhortation to prepare for the Hereafter.

item.title: Divine Power
item.description: The surah highlights Allah's power through natural phenomena.

item.title: Resurrection and Judgment
item.description: It affirms the reality of resurrection and the final Day of Judgment.

item.title: Prophetic Stories
item.description: The stories of the prophets serve as lessons on the continuity of the divine message and the consequences of disbelief.

item.title: Call to Faith
item.description: The surah encourages people to embrace faith and prepare for the Hereafter.

section.introduction: Surah At-Tur (The Mount) is the 52nd surah of the Quran, consisting of 49 verses. It is named after the mountain mentioned in the first verse, symbolizing the grandeur and stability of divine creation. The surah addresses themes of resurrection, the final judgment, and signs of Allah in the universe. It highlights the consequences for disbelievers and rewards for believers. The surah also recounts the stories of past prophets, such as Moses, to remind of the truth of the divine message and the necessity of following God's teachings.
section.title: Oaths by Divine Signs

item.title: Oaths by Sacred Elements
item.description: The surah begins with a series of oaths where Allah swears by sacred and significant elements, such as the Mount (Tur), the Written Book, the Frequented House (Kaaba), and the Elevated Sky. These oaths emphasize the greatness and importance of the message that follows.

section.title: The Day of Judgment and Its Consequences

item.title: Resurrection and Judgment
item.description: The surah describes the Day of Judgment as an inevitable event where the heavens will split and the mountains will collapse. It warns about the reality of this day and its consequences for believers and disbelievers.

item.title: Reward for Believers
item.description: It depicts the blessings and rewards awaiting believers in Paradise, contrasted with the punishments reserved for disbelievers.

item.title: Skepticism of Disbelievers
item.description: The surah addresses the attitude of disbelievers who doubt the prophetic message and resurrection. It refutes their objections and highlights the folly of their skepticism.

item.title: Punishment of Disbelievers
item.description: The consequences of disbelief are described vividly, with scenes of the punishment awaiting them in the Hereafter.

item.title: Consolation for the Prophet
item.description: The surah offers words of comfort to Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), encouraging him to continue his mission despite opposition and difficulties.

item.title: Certainty of the Message
item.description: It reaffirms the truth and certainty of the divine message and encourages the Prophet to persevere in his mission.

item.title: Oaths by Divine Signs
item.description: Verses 1-6: Oaths by the Mount, the Written Book, the Frequented House, and the Elevated Sky to emphasize the importance of the message.

item.title: The Day of Judgment and Its Consequences
item.description: Verses 7-16: Description of the Day of Judgment, rewards for believers, and punishments for disbelievers.

item.title: Reactions of Disbelievers
item.description: Verses 17-28: Critique of disbelievers' skepticism and scenes of punishment in the Hereafter.

item.title: Prophet’s Mission
item.description: Verses 29-49: Encouragement for Prophet Muhammad to persevere in his mission and affirmation of the divine message’s truth.

item.title: Divine Oaths
item.description: The surah begins with solemn oaths that highlight the greatness of the following message.

item.title: Day of Judgment
item.description: It vividly describes the Day of Judgment and its consequences for believers and disbelievers.

item.title: Critique of Disbelievers
item.description: The surah refutes the objections of disbelievers and highlights the consequences of their skepticism.

item.title: Encouragement for the Prophet
item.description: It offers comfort and encouragement to the Prophet in his prophetic mission.

section.introduction: Surah An-Najm (The Star) is the 53rd surah of the Quran, consisting of 62 verses. It is named after the star mentioned in the first verse, symbolizing celestial signs and the grandeur of God. The surah addresses themes of divine revelation, monotheism, and the Last Judgment. It emphasizes the truth of the prophetic message and the importance of following God's teachings. The surah also recalls the stories of peoples who rejected prophets and the consequences they faced. It stresses the necessity of faith, submission to God, and adherence to His commandments.
section.title: Proof of Revelation

item.title: Oath by the Star
item.description: The surah begins with an oath by the star when it descends, highlighting the grandeur and truthfulness of the prophetic message that follows.

item.title: Authentic Revelation
item.description: It confirms the authenticity of the revelation received by Prophet Muhammad and asserts that he is not astray, emphasizing that his words are the revelation from Allah transmitted through the angel Gabriel.

item.title: Nocturnal Journey
item.description: The surah describes the nocturnal journey (Isra) and the ascension to the heavens (Mi'raj) of the Prophet, including his encounter with the angel Gabriel and the wonders he observed.

item.title: Vision of the Lotus of the Limit
item.description: It refers to the vision of the Lotus of the Limit (Sidrat al-Muntaha) during the heavenly ascension, a place of high spiritual significance.

item.title: Critique of Idolatry
item.description: The surah refutes the polytheistic beliefs of the Meccans who worshipped idols like Al-Lat, Al-'Uzza, and Manat. It asserts that these idols have no divine reality and that worship should be exclusively reserved for Allah.

item.title: Condemnation of Erroneous Traditions
item.description: It criticizes the erroneous traditions and beliefs of polytheists who followed unfounded assumptions.

item.title: Accountability for Actions
item.description: The surah emphasizes individual responsibility, highlighting that each person is responsible for their own actions and no one will bear the burden of another.

item.title: Recompense
item.description: It asserts that everyone will be recompensed according to their deeds, whether good or bad.

item.title: Power of Allah
item.description: The surah concludes by reminding of Allah’s power and inviting people to reflect on the signs in creation and acknowledge His absolute authority over the universe.

item.title: Proof of Revelation
item.description: Verses 1-18: Oath by the star, authenticity of the revelation, and description of the Prophet Muhammad’s heavenly ascension.

item.title: Refutation of Polytheistic Beliefs
item.description: Verses 19-26: Critique of idols and polytheistic beliefs of the Meccans.

item.title: Personal Responsibility
item.description: Verses 27-32: Assertion of individual responsibility and recompense based on actions.

item.title: Divine Power
item.description: Verses 33-62: Reminder of Allah’s power and exhortation to worship Him alone.

item.title: Truthfulness of Revelation
item.description: The surah begins by establishing the truthfulness of the revelation received by Prophet Muhammad.

item.title: Heavenly Ascension
item.description: It references the Prophet’s heavenly ascension, a key event in Islam.

item.title: Critique of Idolatry
item.description: The surah refutes polytheistic beliefs and emphasizes monotheism.

item.title: Individual Responsibility
item.description: It reminds that each person is accountable for their actions and will face the consequences.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Qamar (The Moon) is the 54th surah of the Quran, consisting of 55 verses. It is named after the moon mentioned in the first verse, referring to a miracle attributed to the Prophet Muhammad, where the moon was split into two. The surah addresses themes of resurrection, the Last Judgment, and signs of God. It recounts the stories of the prophets Noah, Abraham, Lot, and Moses, highlighting the consequences for the people who rejected divine messages. The surah emphasizes the truthfulness of the prophetic message, signs of God in nature, and the importance of faith and repentance.
section.title: The Miracle of the Moon's Splitting

item.title: The Miraculous Event
item.description: The surah begins by mentioning a miracle where the Moon was split in two, a sign meant for the Meccans to confirm Muhammad's prophecy (peace and blessings be upon him). Despite this obvious sign, the disbelievers view it as mere illusion and continue to reject the truth.

section.title: The Ancient Peoples and Their Destruction

item.title: Examples of the Ancients
item.description: The surah recounts the stories of ancient peoples who also rejected their prophets' warnings, such as the people of Noah, the 'Aad, the Thamud, the people of Lot, and the Egyptians under Pharaoh.

item.title: Consequences of Rejection
item.description: Each story illustrates how these peoples were destroyed by divine punishments due to their obstinacy and disbelief.

item.title: Repetition of the Message
item.description: Several times, the surah emphasizes the importance of remembering the warnings and learning lessons from past stories. It repeats the phrase "We have made the Quran easy to remember. Is there anyone who will reflect?" to stress the accessibility of the message and the need to meditate upon it.

item.title: Warning to the Meccans
item.description: The Meccans are warned that they will face a similar fate to that of the ancient peoples if they persist in their disbelief.

item.title: Description of Judgment
item.description: The surah vividly describes the Day of Judgment, with scenes of confusion and despair for the disbelievers, and the certainty of recompense for the believers.

item.title: Divine Justice
item.description: It highlights Allah's justice, who rewards the pious and punishes the unjust.

item.title: The Miracle of the Moon's Splitting
item.description: Verses 1-2: Mention of the moon splitting miracle and the disbelievers' rejection.

item.title: Stories of the Ancient Peoples
item.description: Verses 9-42: Accounts of the people of Noah, 'Aad, Thamud, Lot, and Pharaoh, and their destruction due to disbelief.

item.title: Reminder and Warning
item.description: Verses 17, 22, 32, 40: Repetition of the message and encouragement to reflect on the lessons from the past.

item.title: The Day of Judgment
item.description: Verses 43-55: Description of the Day of Judgment, the confusion of the disbelievers, and recompense for the believers.

item.title: Miracle and Skepticism
item.description: The surah begins with a miracle meant to convince the disbelievers, but their persistent skepticism is highlighted.

item.title: Lessons from the Ancients
item.description: It recalls the stories of ancient peoples to underscore the consequences of rejecting divine warnings.

item.title: Accessibility of the Message
item.description: The Quran is described as easy to memorize and understand, urging people to reflect on its teachings.

item.title: Warning of Judgment
item.description: The surah warns the disbelievers of the Day of Judgment and highlights divine justice.

section.introduction: Surah Ar-Rahman (The Most Merciful) is the 55th surah of the Quran, consisting of 78 verses. It is named after one of God's attributes, "Ar-Rahman," meaning "The Most Merciful." The surah celebrates the divine blessings and mercies by enumerating the signs of God in creation, such as the heavens, the earth, and living creatures. It deals with the recognition of divine blessings and gratitude towards God. The surah also highlights the rewards for the pious and the consequences for those who ignore God's signs. It is known for its repeated question, "Which of the favors of your Lord will you deny?", emphasizing the importance of recognition and gratitude.
section.title: God’s Blessings

item.title: Name of Allah: Ar-Rahman
item.description: The surah begins with the name of Allah, "Ar-Rahman," which means "The Merciful." This name highlights God's infinite mercy towards all His creatures.

item.title: Creation and Teaching of the Quran
item.description: Allah is described as having taught the Quran, created man, and given him the ability to speak. These gifts are presented as some of the first divine blessings mentioned.

item.title: The Heavens and the Earth
item.description: The surah discusses the creation of the heavens, the earth, and the balance governing the universe, encouraging people to reflect on the precision and harmony of creation.

item.title: Natural Blessings
item.description: It continues by describing various natural blessings, such as plants, fruits, water, seas with their pearls and corals, and mountains. These descriptions are interspersed with the refrain reminding humans and jinn not to deny these favors.

item.title: Description of the Day of Judgment
item.description: The surah refers to the Day of Judgment, where everyone will be rewarded or punished according to their deeds. The blessings of Paradise are described in contrast to the punishments of Hell.

item.title: Promises of Reward
item.description: For the righteous, the surah describes gardens of delight with flowing rivers, abundant fruits, and pure companions.

item.title: Repeated Refrain
item.description: The surah uses the refrain "Which of the favors of your Lord will you deny?" to emphasize the diversity and abundance of divine blessings. This refrain addresses both humans and jinn, reminding them to acknowledge and submit to Allah.

item.title: God’s Blessings
item.description: Verses 1-13: Allah, The Merciful, teaches the Quran, creates man, and establishes balance in the universe.

item.title: Signs of Creation
item.description: Verses 14-45: Description of natural elements, seas, heavens, and mountains as signs of divine power.

item.title: Recompense for Actions
item.description: Verses 46-78: Description of the Day of Judgment, the rewards of Paradise for the righteous, and the punishments of Hell for the disbelievers.

item.title: The Call to Gratitude
item.description: Verses 13, 16, 18...: Repetition of the refrain urging recognition of divine blessings.

item.title: Mercy of Allah
item.description: The surah highlights Allah’s mercy, visible in creation, the teaching of the Quran, and the numerous blessings granted to creatures.

item.title: Reflection on Creation
item.description: It invites reflection on the wonders of creation as evidence of Allah’s greatness.

item.title: Just Recompense
item.description: The surah addresses Allah’s justice by promising reward for the pious and punishment for the disbelievers.

item.title: Gratitude
item.description: The repetitive refrain reminds the importance of gratitude for Allah’s numerous blessings.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Waqi'ah (The Event) is the 56th surah of the Quran, consisting of 96 verses. Its name refers to the "event," which denotes the Day of Judgment. The surah details the events that will occur at the end of the world and the final judgment, dividing people into three groups: the blessed, the people of the right hand, and the wretched. It highlights the rewards for the devout believers and the punishments for the disbelievers. The surah emphasizes the truth of divine revelations and the reality of the afterlife, while reminding of God's greatness and the signs of His creation.
section.title: The Day of Judgment

item.title: Destruction and Transformation
item.description: The surah begins by describing spectacular cosmic events that will occur before the Day of Judgment, such as the total destruction of the universe and the transformation of the heavens and the earth.

item.title: Distribution of Groups
item.description: It explains how people will be divided into three distinct groups on the Day of Judgment: the people of the right (the righteous), the people of the left (the wicked), and the predecessors (the prophets and martyrs).

section.title: The People of the Right Hand

item.title: Rewards
item.description: The believers and the righteous, called the people of the right hand, will be rewarded with the delights of Paradise. The surah describes the gardens, fruits, and pleasures they will experience, highlighting the rewards for their faith and good deeds.

item.title: Visions of an Ideal Paradise
item.description: The rewards are vividly described, emphasizing the lush aspects of Paradise and the eternal joy awaiting the pious.

section.title: The People of the Left Hand

item.title: Punishments
item.description: In contrast, the wicked and disbelievers, called the people of the left hand, will be punished. The surah describes the sufferings and punishments awaiting them in Hell due to their evil deeds and disbelief.

item.title: Details of the Punishments
item.description: The scenes of punishment are detailed to underscore the severity of the consequences for those who reject the signs of God.

item.title: Honorable Place in Paradise
item.description: The surah mentions the predecessors, those who preceded in faith, such as the prophets and martyrs, and their honorable place in Paradise. They are seen as models of faith and sacrifice.

item.title: Reminder of Blessings
item.description: The surah reminds of the blessings that God has granted to humanity, such as food, water, and life itself, and encourages people to reflect on these gifts and recognize the greatness of God.

item.title: Natural Events
item.description: It mentions aspects of creation and natural events as proof of divine power and signs of the Day of Judgment.

item.title: The Day of Judgment
item.description: Verses 1-16: Description of cosmic events and the distribution of people into three groups.

item.title: The People of the Right Hand
item.description: Verses 17-40: Description of the rewards and delights of Paradise for the righteous.

item.title: The People of the Left Hand
item.description: Verses 41-56: Description of the punishments and sufferings for the wicked.

item.title: The Predecessors
item.description: Verses 57-74: Mention of the predecessors and their elevated status in Paradise.

item.title: Reminder and Reflection
item.description: Verses 75-96: Reminder of divine blessings and invitation to reflect on the signs of God.

item.title: Day of Judgment
item.description: The surah describes the Day of Judgment with powerful imagery of destruction and transformation, followed by the division of people into three distinct groups.

item.title: Rewards and Punishments
item.description: It clearly distinguishes the rewards for the righteous and the punishments for the disbelievers.

item.title: Reminder of Blessings
item.description: The surah reminds people of the blessings God has bestowed upon them, urging them to recognize and thank Allah.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Hadid (Iron) is the 57th chapter of the Quran, consisting of 29 verses. It is named after iron, mentioned in verse 25, symbolizing strength and power, as well as the divine blessings associated with this material. The surah addresses themes of faith, divine mercy, and the necessity of perseverance in the path of God. It also covers aspects of wealth, power, and their responsible use for the benefit of humanity. The surah encourages believers to be generous, support the cause of God, and recognize God's signs in creation, while warning against material distractions.
section.title: The Creation and Divine Signs

item.title: Creation of Iron
item.description: Iron is mentioned as a divine blessing and a sign of Allah's power. Its use symbolizes how material blessings are used for the benefit of humanity.

item.title: Divine Signs
item.description: The surah begins with a declaration of Allah's greatness and the universality of His creation. It mentions the creation of the heavens and the earth in six days, emphasizing divine mastery over the universe.

section.title: The Importance of Faith and Righteous Deeds

item.title: Reminder of Faith
item.description: The surah emphasizes the importance of faith in Allah and the practice of charity. Believers are urged to uphold the truth and strive for the well-being of the community.

item.title: Balance of Deeds
item.description: The verses encourage believers to be just and maintain a balance between material and spiritual life. They are called to spend in the way of Allah and not to be distracted by the transient goods of this world.

section.title: The Transitory Nature of Worldly Life

item.title: Temporariness of Possessions
item.description: The surah highlights the temporary nature of material possessions and earthly wealth compared to the eternal life of the Hereafter. It emphasizes the need to focus efforts on preparation for the Hereafter rather than accumulating wealth.

section.title: The Role of Prophets and Revelations

item.title: Mission of Prophets
item.description: The surah discusses the mission of the prophets sent to guide humanity and the difficulties they faced. It highlights the patience and perseverance of believers in the face of trials.

section.title: The Day of Judgment and Retribution

item.title: Divine Justice
item.description: The surah describes the Day of Judgment when every individual will be rewarded or punished according to their deeds. It emphasizes Allah's justice, which is infallible and equitable.

item.title: The Creation and Divine Signs
item.description: Verses 1-6: Praise of Allah’s greatness, mention of the creation of iron, and divine signs in the universe.

item.title: The Importance of Faith and Righteous Deeds
item.description: Verses 7-19: Encouragement to believe in Allah, practice charity, and maintain a balance between material and spiritual aspects of life.

item.title: The Transitory Nature of Worldly Life
item.description: Verses 20-24: Reminder of the transitory nature of earthly possessions and exhortation to focus on the eternal life.

item.title: The Role of Prophets and Revelations
item.description: Verses 25-29: Discussion of the prophets' mission, their patience, and the challenges they faced.

item.title: The Day of Judgment and Retribution
item.description: Verses 30-29: Description of divine justice and retribution for human actions.

item.title: Divine Signs in Creation
item.description: The surah highlights Allah's greatness and the blessings He has granted humanity, such as iron.

item.title: Importance of Faith and Charity
item.description: It encourages believers to practice faith sincerely and support the truth.

item.title: Transience of Worldly Life
item.description: The surah reminds that material possessions are temporary and that the essential focus should be on preparation for the Hereafter.

item.title: Divine Justice
item.description: The surah emphasizes Allah's justice and the equitable retribution on the Day of Judgment.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Mujādila (The Dispute) is the 58th surah of the Quran, consisting of 22 verses. It is named after the term "mujādila," meaning "the dispute," referring to the story of a woman who had a dispute with Prophet Muhammad regarding a family law issue. The surah addresses various themes, including family relations, justice, and rules concerning the behavior of believers. section.introduction: Surah Al-Ma'ārij (The Ascending Paths) is the 70th surah of the Quran, consisting of 44 verses. It deals with the trials and ascending paths of life, referring to the spiritual and material challenges faced by believers. The surah describes the signs of the Day of Judgment, highlighting the consequences for the disbelievers and the rewards for the righteous. It emphasizes the patience needed in the face of difficulties and the truthfulness of divine judgment. The surah underscores the characteristics of true believers, their perseverance in faith, and their exemplary behavior. It calls for an increased awareness of divine truth and a sincere commitment to God.

section.introduction: Surah Nuh (Noah) is the 71st surah of the Quran, consisting of 28 verses. It recounts the story of Prophet Noah and the challenges he faced in preaching the oneness of God to his people. The surah describes Noah's persistence in guiding his people despite their rejection and disbelief. It highlights the patience of the prophet and the consequences of divine rejection, including the flood that destroyed the disbelievers. The surah emphasizes themes of faith, repentance, and the deliverance of the faithful believers. It calls on believers to recognize God's signs and follow the teachings of the prophets.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Jinn (The Jinn) is the 72nd surah of the Quran, consisting of 28 verses. It addresses the issue of the jinn, invisible creatures created by God from fire, and their interaction with humanity. The surah recounts how a group of jinn heard the Prophet Muhammad recite the Quran and were impressed by its teachings, converting to Islam. It highlights the reality of the jinn, their ability to listen to divine revelations, and their responsibility before God. The surah underscores the truth of the revelation and the necessity for everyone, including the jinn, to submit to God's will. It calls for the recognition of God's oneness and seeking His guidance.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Muzzammil (The Enshrouded One) is the 73rd surah of the Quran, consisting of 20 verses. It begins with the call to "the Enshrouded One" (referring to the Prophet Muhammad meditating under a cloak) and addresses the responsibilities associated with the prophetic mission. The surah encourages the Prophet to dedicate himself to worshiping God at night, to pray, and to recite the Quran with great focus. It also discusses patience in the face of opposition and the challenges encountered in the prophetic mission. The surah emphasizes the importance of perseverance in faith and the need to prepare for the trials to come. It calls for deep devotion and spiritual preparation for divine responsibilities.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Muddathir (The Cloaked One) is the 74th surah of the Quran, consisting of 56 verses. The surah commands the Prophet to rise and warn the people, purify himself, and prepare for the challenges of his mission. It describes the consequences of disbelief and denial, highlighting the punishments reserved for the reprobate. The surah also emphasizes the necessity of patience and perseverance in the face of difficulties. It calls for worshiping God alone and personal purification as a prerequisite for fulfilling the divine mission.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Qiyāmah (The Resurrection) is the 75th surah of the Quran, consisting of 40 verses. It primarily addresses the Day of Resurrection and the final judgment. The surah describes the events that will occur at the end of the world, the resurrection of the dead, and the presentation of deeds before God. It highlights the certainty of resurrection, the consequences for both believers and disbelievers, and the divine retribution based on human actions. The surah emphasizes the reality of the afterlife and encourages believers to prepare for judgment by leading a righteous and pious life. It reminds of the importance of faith and consciousness of God in all actions.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Insān (Man) is the 76th surah of the Quran, consisting of 31 verses. It deals with the creation of man from a drop of sperm and the divine guidance given to humanity for leading a virtuous life. The surah describes the blessings granted by God to the pious believers and the rewards reserved for the righteous in the Hereafter. It also addresses the trials that believers may encounter in their lives and the need to remain patient and grateful. The surah emphasizes human responsibility towards God, gratitude for His blessings, and the promise of divine mercy for those who follow the right path.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Mursalat (The Sent Ones) is the 77th surah of the Quran, consisting of 50 verses. The surah describes the signs of God in creation, the events of the end of the world, and the Day of Judgment. It highlights the consequences of rejecting divine truth, emphasizing the punishments reserved for the disbelievers and the rewards for the righteous. The surah stresses the truthfulness of the revelations and the necessity of sincere faith, calling people to recognize the divine signs in the world around them.

section.introduction: Surah An-Naba' (The Announcement) is the 78th surah of the Quran, consisting of 40 verses. The surah describes God's signs in creation, the Day of Resurrection, and the catastrophic events that will accompany the end of the world. It highlights the rewards for the righteous believers and the punishments for the disbelievers. The surah emphasizes the truth of resurrection and the importance of recognizing and preparing for the final judgment. It encourages believers to reflect on God's signs and live according to His commandments.

The surah deals with the events of the end of the world, resurrection, and the Day of Judgment. It describes God's signs, the punishments reserved for the wicked, and the rewards for the righteous believers. The surah also recounts the story of Moses and Pharaoh to illustrate the consequences of disbelief and divine power. It calls for reflection on the truth of resurrection and encourages believers to follow divine teachings with sincerity and devotion.

item.description: Verses 46-51: Call to embrace faith, reflection on divine signs, and encouragement to lead a pious life in preparation for the Day of Judgment. These verses encourage reflection on God's signs and spiritual preparation for the Final Judgment.

item.title: The Snatchers
item.description: The surah describes the role of the snatching angels in the resurrection process and the Last Judgment, highlighting their strength and precision in executing divine commands.

item.title: Prophets' Stories
item.description: The surah recounts the story of Moses and his interactions with Pharaoh to illustrate the consequences of rebellion against God.

item.title: Rewards and Punishments
item.description: The surah contrasts the rewards for the righteous with the punishments for the disbelievers, using evocative imagery of consequences in the Hereafter.

item.title: Spiritual Reflection
item.description: The surah encourages faith, reflection on divine signs, and spiritual preparation for the Day of Judgment, emphasizing the importance of leading a life in accordance with God's commandments.

section.introduction: Surah Abasa (He Frowned) is the 80th surah of the Quran, consisting of 42 verses. It begins with an episode where Prophet Muhammad frowns in response to the arrival of a blind man while discussing with the notable leaders of Quraysh. The surah addresses themes of compassion, equality, and the importance of spiritual guidance for everyone, regardless of their social status. It describes God's signs in creation and the consequences for those who reject the truth. The surah reminds of the importance of personal responsibility and gratitude towards God, emphasizing the need to treat each individual with respect and fairness.
section.title: The Incident with the Blind Man

item.title: The Incident with the Blind Man
item.description: Verses 1-10: Critique of Prophet Muhammad's frowning in the presence of Abdullah ibn Umm Maktum, a blind man. This section reminds of the importance of welcoming and guiding all believers with kindness, highlighting that social status or physical abilities should not influence our behavior towards others.

item.title: The Judgment and Rewards
item.description: Verses 11-16: Description of the Day of Judgment, presenting rewards for the pious and punishments for the disbelievers. This section highlights the consequences of human actions and divine justice on the Last Day.

item.title: God's Signs
item.description: Verses 17-32: Reflection on God's signs in creation, such as fields of grain, palm trees, and grapes. This section emphasizes the importance of recognizing and thanking God for His blessings by observing the divine signs present in nature.

item.title: Behavior and Ethics
item.description: Verses 33-42: Reminder of the importance of treating all individuals with fairness and compassion, regardless of their social status. This section stresses the ethical responsibility of treating each person well, reflecting values of justice and humanity.

item.title: The Incident with the Blind Man
item.description: The surah critiques the Prophet's attitude towards a blind man and emphasizes the importance of welcoming all believers with kindness, regardless of their condition.

item.title: Judgment and Rewards
item.description: The surah describes the Last Judgment and the consequences of individual actions, offering rewards for the pious and punishments for the disbelievers.

item.title: God's Signs
item.description: The surah invites reflection on the divine signs in creation and being grateful for the blessings God provides.

item.title: Ethical Behavior
item.description: The surah stresses the responsibility of treating all people with fairness and compassion, regardless of their social status or abilities.

section.introduction: Surah At-Takwir (The Overthrowing) is the 81st surah of the Quran, consisting of 29 verses. It describes the signs of the end of the world and the Day of Judgment with powerful and evocative imagery. The surah mentions the darkening of the stars, the decline of the sun, and the cosmic upheavals that will mark the end of the universe. It emphasizes the resurrection of the dead and the presentation of human actions for judgment. The surah highlights the rewards for the righteous believers and the punishments for the disbelievers, while reminding of the truth and reality of the Day of Judgment. It encourages people to reflect on God's greatness and prepare their souls for the afterlife.
section.title: The Signs of the End of the World

item.title: The Signs of the End of the World
item.description: Verses 1-14: Description of major cosmic events such as the darkening of the sun, the falling of the stars, and the collapse of the mountains. These verses illustrate the gravity of the Day of Judgment and the cataclysmic transformations that will mark the end of the world.

item.title: The Judgment and the Reward
item.description: Verses 15-29: Description of the contrasting destinies of the righteous and the wicked. The verses highlight the rewards reserved for the pious and the punishments for the impious, emphasizing the importance of actions and divine justice in the afterlife.

item.title: The Prophet's Mission
item.description: Verses 30-31: Reminder of Prophet Muhammad's role as a divine messenger and guide for the believers. These verses highlight the importance of following the Prophet's teachings and respecting his instructions.

item.title: The Message of the Surah
item.description: Verses 32-36: Call to reflect on the signs of the end of the world. Encouragement to lead a life of piety and righteousness, and an invitation to trust in God despite the trials and signs heralding the end.

item.title: Signs of the End of the World
item.description: The surah describes the major cosmic events that will precede the Last Judgment, highlighting the gravity and significance of these signs.

item.title: Judgment and Reward
item.description: It illustrates the contrasting fate of the righteous and the wicked, emphasizing the consequences of human actions in the afterlife.

item.title: Prophet's Mission
item.description: The surah reminds of the crucial role of Prophet Muhammad as God's messenger and guide for the believers.

item.title: Message of Reflection
item.description: The surah encourages reflection on divine signs and leading a pious life in preparation for the Last Judgment.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Infitar (The Cleaving Open) is the 82nd surah of the Quran, consisting of 19 verses. It describes the signs of the end of the world, highlighting the cleaving open of the heavens and the stars, as well as the cosmic upheavals that will mark the Day of Judgment. The surah discusses the resurrection of the dead and the presentation of human actions for judgment. It emphasizes the rewards for the righteous believers and the punishments for the disbelievers, stressing the truth of resurrection and the importance of spiritual preparation. The surah calls for reflection on divine signs and encourages people to lead a just and pious life in preparation for the afterlife.
section.title: The Cataclysmic Events

item.title: The Cataclysmic Events
item.description: Verses 1-5: Description of major cosmic phenomena such as the cleaving of the sky, the falling of the stars, and the transformation of the earth. These verses illustrate the complete upheaval of the cosmic order on the Day of Judgment.

item.title: The Judgment and the Reward
item.description: Verses 6-14: Revelation of individuals' actions and the separation of the righteous from the wicked. The righteous will be rewarded with eternal delights, while the wicked will face severe punishments. These verses highlight the importance of actions and moral choices.

item.title: The Message of the Surah
item.description: Verses 15-19: Call to reflect on the signs of the Day of Judgment. Encouragement to live a life of piety and righteousness, and emphasis on personal responsibility for actions. These verses underscore the importance of preparing one's soul for the Day of Judgment.

item.title: Cataclysmic Phenomena
item.description: The surah describes the major cosmic upheavals that will occur on the Day of Judgment, illustrating the radical change in the natural order.

item.title: Revelation of Actions
item.description: It highlights the importance of individual actions and their consequences, with a clear separation between the righteous and the wicked.

item.title: Personal Responsibility
item.description: The surah emphasizes each individual's responsibility for their deeds and encourages leading a moral and just life.

item.title: Reflection and Preparation
item.description: It calls for reflection on the reality of the Last Judgment and preparation by following Islamic principles.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Mutaffifīn (The Defrauders) is the 83rd surah of the Quran, consisting of 36 verses. It deals with economic injustices, particularly fraudulent practices in commercial transactions, such as reducing weights and measures. The surah condemns those who cheat and deceive others, emphasizing that such actions will be severely punished on the Day of Judgment. It also describes the fate of the righteous believers who will be rewarded for their honesty and integrity. The surah highlights the consequences of unjust actions and encourages people to uphold principles of fairness and justice in their dealings. It reminds that every act, even the smallest, is recorded and will be judged by God.
section.title: Fraud and Dishonesty

item.title: Fraud and Dishonesty
item.description: Verses 1-3: Description of defrauders and their deceptive practices in commercial transactions. These verses highlight the unjust actions aimed at making dishonest gains.

item.title: The Judgment of the Dishonest
item.description: Verses 4-16: Consequences of fraud, including the fate of the defrauders on the Day of Judgment and the reward for the righteous. These verses emphasize the severity of punishment for wrongdoers and mercy for those who act with integrity.

item.title: The Message of the Surah
item.description: Verses 17-28: Importance of integrity and justice, with a call to act honestly and reflect on divine justice. The surah insists on avoiding deceptive practices and following just principles.

item.title: Fraud and Dishonesty
item.description: The surah condemns fraudulent practices in commercial transactions and measures, highlighting the injustice and disadvantages of such practices.

item.title: Consequences at Judgment
item.description: It warns of the severe consequences for defrauders on the Day of Judgment, illustrating the severity of divine justice.

item.title: Reward for the Righteous
item.description: Honest individuals will be rewarded for their integrity and sincerity, contrasting with the fate of wrongdoers.

item.title: Importance of Integrity
item.description: The surah emphasizes the importance of integrity and calls on believers to avoid deceptive practices in all transactions and interactions.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Inshiqaq (The Fissure) is the 84th chapter of the Quran, consisting of 25 verses. It describes the cataclysmic events that will occur at the end of the world, such as the fissuring of the heavens and the transformation of the earth. The surah mentions the resurrection of the dead, the presentation of human actions before God, and the consequences for believers and disbelievers. It emphasizes the truth of the Day of Judgment and the reward for the pious as well as the punishment for the unjust. The surah calls people to reflect on divine signs and prepare for the final judgment by leading a life in accordance with God's commandments.
section.title: The Cataclysmic Events

item.title: The Cataclysmic Events
item.description: Verses 1-5: Description of the splitting of the sky, the transformation of the earth, and the revelation of individual actions. These phenomena illustrate the complete upheaval of the cosmic order and the manifestation of what was hidden.

item.title: The Judgment of Individuals
item.description: Verses 6-14: Revelation of individual actions, with a detailed description of the fate reserved for the righteous and the wicked. The righteous will receive eternal delights, while the wicked will face severe punishments.

item.title: The Message of the Surah
item.description: Verses 15-25: Importance of actions in divine judgment, reflection on the Last Judgment, and encouragement to lead a righteous life. The surah calls for awareness of actions and piety.

item.title: Cataclysmic Events
item.description: The surah describes major cosmic upheavals, such as the splitting of the sky and the transformation of the earth, marking the Day of Judgment.

item.title: Revelation of Actions
item.description: The actions of individuals will be revealed and judged, influencing their fate in the hereafter.

item.title: Reward and Punishment
item.description: The righteous will be rewarded with eternal pleasures, while the wicked will be severely punished.

item.title: Importance of Piety
item.description: The surah emphasizes the necessity of living a life of piety and adherence to Islamic principles in preparation for the Last Judgment.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Burooj (The Constellations) is the 85th chapter of the Quran, consisting of 22 verses. It is named after the "constellations" mentioned in the first verse, referring to the starry heavens. The surah addresses themes of faith, the persecution of believers, and the consequences for oppressors. It narrates the story of the believers persecuted under the reign of King Dhu Nuwas, highlighting the divine reward for those who remained steadfast in their faith despite trials. The surah emphasizes the sovereignty of God and the punishments reserved for disbelievers and the unjust. It calls on believers to have patience, perseverance, and trust in divine justice in the face of oppression.
section.title: The Persecution of Believers

item.title: The Persecution of Believers
item.description: Verses 1-10: Description of the constellations and grand palaces as symbols of divine majesty. The surah then discusses the persecution of believers, including trials such as blazing pits and severe burns.

item.title: Judgment and Divine Retribution
item.description: Verses 11-16: Retribution of the oppressors with a description of the severe punishments reserved for the wicked. The pious will be rewarded and protected by divine justice.

item.title: The Message of the Surah
item.description: Verses 17-22: Reflection on divine justice, encouragement to be patient, and assurance that divine justice will prevail despite the believers' suffering.

item.title: Persecution of Believers
item.description: The surah describes the severe persecutions endured by the believers, including the cruel acts of the wicked like blazing pits.

item.title: Divine Justice
item.description: The surah emphasizes that divine justice is inevitable, and oppressors will be punished while the pious will be rewarded.

item.title: Importance of Patience
item.description: Encouragement to maintain patience and faith despite trials, with the assurance that God is aware of the believers' sufferings.

item.title: Fair Retribution
item.description: The surah teaches that every action will be judged by God with fair retribution according to the deeds of individuals.

section.introduction: Surah At-Tāriq (The Morning Star) is the 86th chapter of the Quran, consisting of 17 verses. It is named after "at-tāriq", which means "the morning star" or "the shining star". The surah describes the creation of man and the truth of resurrection by highlighting the power of God in creation and the renewal of life. It discusses the Day of Judgment, the resurrection of the dead, and the human actions that will be judged. The surah emphasizes the rewards for devout believers and the punishments for disbelievers, while reminding of the truth and importance of faith in the context of the afterlife. It encourages people to reflect on the signs of God and prepare for the final judgment.
section.title: Heavenly Phenomena

item.title: Heavenly Phenomena
item.description: Verses 1-3: The surah begins by swearing by the shooting star, illustrating divine greatness. It also addresses the creation of man and God's protection over every creature.

item.title: Judgment and Divine Retribution
item.description: Verses 4-14: Description of the Day of Judgment where every soul will be judged according to its deeds. The actions of individuals will be revealed, and believers will receive rewards while the wicked will face punishment.

item.title: The Message of the Surah
item.description: Verses 15-17: Invitation to reflect on divine creation and the perfection of God's creations. Encouragement to maintain faith and prepare for the Judgment.

item.title: Heavenly Phenomena
item.description: The surah uses the shooting star as a symbol of divine greatness and creation.

item.title: Inevitable Judgment
item.description: The Day of Judgment is presented as inevitable, with fair retribution for the actions of individuals.

item.title: Reflection on Creation
item.description: The surah invites reflection on the perfection of divine creation and strengthening faith in God.

item.title: Importance of Faith
item.description: Encouragement to maintain faith and prepare for Judgment by leading a life in accordance with Islamic principles.

section.title: The Praise of God
section.verses: Verses 1-2: The surah begins by praising the greatness of God, the Creator of the heavens and the earth. It highlights the divine majesty and His attributes of exaltation and perfection.

section.title: Creation and Divine Guidance
section.verses: Verses 3-7: Description of the creation of man by God, emphasizing the perfection of creation and divine wisdom in forming the human being. The surah stresses the divine guidance to lead a moral and just life.

section.verses: Verses 8-19: Invitation to meditate on divine creation, acknowledgment of God's blessings, importance of gratitude, and necessity to follow divine guidance to lead a virtuous life.
