sub-section.title: Reflection and Gratitude
sub-section.content: It encourages believers to reflect on God's creation, be grateful, and live according to divine principles.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Ghashiyah (The Overwhelming) is the 88th surah of the Quran, consisting of 26 verses. It describes the events of the Day of Judgment, highlighting the scene of chaos and overshadowing for the disbelievers, while the believers will enjoy peace and rest. The surah discusses the rewards reserved for the righteous and the punishments for the damned, emphasizing the greatness and justice of God. It encourages people to reflect on the signs of divine creation and acknowledge the truth of resurrection. The surah calls for consciousness of God and spiritual preparation for the final judgment, reminding of the consequences of human actions in this life and the Hereafter.
section.title: The Overwhelming Day

item.title: The Overwhelming Day
item.description: Verses 1-7: The surah describes the Day of Judgment as a majestic and overwhelming event, marked by cosmic phenomena and divine retribution. It highlights the distinction between the destinies of the believers and the disbelievers.

item.title: Signs of God
item.description: Verses 8-16: The surah invites reflection on the natural signs of God in nature, such as mountains, clouds, and the earth. These signs testify to divine power and serve as lessons for humanity.

item.title: The Message of the Surah
item.description: Verses 17-26: Invitation to meditate on creation, the importance of faith in God, and preparation for Judgment. The surah encourages believers to lead a virtuous life in recognition of divine signs.

item.title: Overwhelming Day
item.description: The surah describes the Day of Judgment as an apocalyptic event, enveloping creation and highlighting divine retribution.

item.title: Reward and Punishment
item.description: It emphasizes divine retribution with rewards for the righteous and punishments for the wicked, highlighting divine justice.

item.title: Reflection on Creation
item.description: The surah encourages reflection on the natural signs of God as proof of His greatness and the reality of the Last Judgment.

item.title: Importance of Faith
item.description: It teaches that faith in God and recognition of His signs are essential for receiving divine reward and avoiding punishment.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Fajr (The Dawn) is the 89th surah of the Quran, consisting of 30 verses. It is named after "al-fajr", which means "the dawn" or "the daybreak". The surah addresses the signs of God, the consequences of injustice, and divine retribution for both believers and disbelievers. It recounts the story of ancient peoples, such as `Ād and Thamūd, who were destroyed for their disbelief and oppression. The surah emphasizes the importance of justice and faith, encouraging people to reflect on the signs of God and prepare their hearts for the final judgment. It reminds of the truth of resurrection and divine justice, calling believers to piety and awareness of God.
section.title: The Dawn and Natural Elements

item.title: The Dawn and Natural Elements
item.description: Verses 1-14: The surah begins with oaths by the dawn and other natural elements, illustrating the certainty of the Day of Judgment. It describes ancient civilizations, such as the `Ād and Thamūd, and their punishment for disbelief, highlighting the truth of the forthcoming events.

item.title: Signs of God and Reflection
item.description: Verses 15-20: The surah invites reflection on the retribution of ancient peoples as signs of divine justice. It emphasizes the importance of recognizing the signs of God and the consequences of disbelief.

item.title: The Message of the Surah
item.description: Verses 21-30: Invitation to learn from past civilizations, recognition of God’s blessings, and spiritual preparation for the Day of Judgment. The surah encourages believers to prepare by reflecting on divine signs and acknowledging the blessings received.

item.title: Dawn of Retribution
item.description: The surah uses the dawn as a symbol of the certainty of the Day of Judgment and divine retribution, highlighting the importance of truth and divine justice.

item.title: Retribution of Ancient Peoples
item.description: It highlights the stories of past civilizations, such as the `Ād and Thamūd, as warnings about the consequences of disbelief and injustice.

item.title: Importance of Faith and Gratitude
item.description: The surah emphasizes the necessity of faith, recognizing the signs of God, and gratitude for His blessings, stressing that these elements are crucial for receiving divine retribution.

item.title: Reflection and Preparation
item.description: It encourages believers to reflect on the lessons from past peoples and prepare spiritually for the Day of Judgment, being aware of divine signs and adopting an attitude of gratitude.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Balad (The City) is the 90th surah of the Quran, consisting of 20 verses. It is named after "al-balad", which means "the city", referring to Mecca, the holy city of Prophet Muhammad. The surah addresses the themes of the city, the challenges faced by its inhabitants, and the tests people undergo. It describes the trials of human life, including economic and social difficulties, while emphasizing that success comes through faith, patience, and good deeds. The surah highlights the importance of social justice and compassion towards the less fortunate, and emphasizes divine rewards for those who lead a just and pious life. It calls for a deep consciousness of God and individual responsibility in facing life's challenges.
section.title: Importance of Mecca

item.title: Importance of Mecca
item.description: Verses 1-10: The surah begins with oaths concerning Mecca, highlighting its spiritual importance and status as a sacred land. It also describes the difficulties faced by its inhabitants.

item.title: Trials and Rewards
item.description: Verses 11-20: This section discusses the trials that believers face, such as poverty and hardships. It emphasizes the rewards for those who endure these trials with patience and perseverance.

item.title: Moral and Spiritual Message
item.description: Verses 21-35: The surah stresses the importance of virtuous actions, helping those in need, and viewing trials as divine tests. It teaches that good deeds and patience are essential for receiving divine favor.

item.title: Importance of Mecca
item.description: The surah highlights the spiritual and sacred significance of Mecca, affirming its unique status among lands.

item.title: Trials and Rewards
item.description: It emphasizes the relationship between trials, patience, and divine rewards, highlighting that difficulties are an opportunity to gain spiritual rewards.

item.title: Virtuous Actions
item.description: The surah teaches that virtuous actions and helping others are crucial for receiving divine favor and ensuring a reward in the afterlife.

item.title: Reflection on Trials
item.description: It encourages viewing trials as tests of faith and opportunities to strengthen one’s character and faith, inviting believers to persevere and remain pious.

section.introduction: Surah Ash-Shams (The Sun) is the 91st surah of the Quran, consisting of 15 verses. It is named after "ash-shams," which means "the sun." The surah reflects on the signs of God in nature, starting with the sun, the moon, and other natural elements. It highlights divine creation and the necessity of purifying the soul. The surah recounts the story of the people of Thamūd and their prophet Salih, emphasizing the consequences of their rejection of the truth and disbelief. It stresses the responsibility of humans to choose the path of virtue and spiritual purity. The surah calls for reflection on God's signs and encourages believers to lead a righteous and pious life in harmony with divine teachings.
section.title: The Oaths by Natural Elements

item.title: The Oaths by the Sun and the Moon
item.description: Verses 1-10: The surah begins with oaths by natural elements such as the sun, the moon, the day, and the night, illustrating their role in creation and divine order. These elements symbolize clarity, light, and divine guidance.

item.title: The Purification of the Soul
item.description: Verses 11-15: This section distinguishes between the pure soul and the corrupt soul. It emphasizes the importance of actions in purifying the soul and the necessity of living a righteous life to gain divine approval.

item.title: The Moral and Spiritual Message
item.description: Verses 16-21: The surah deals with the consequences of human actions, lessons from past peoples, and divine retribution based on the purity of the soul. Virtuous actions lead to the purification of the soul, while evil actions lead to corruption.

item.title: Natural Elements as Symbols
item.description: The surah uses natural elements like the sun and the moon to symbolize divine truth and the order of creation.

item.title: Purification of the Soul
item.description: It highlights the importance of purifying the soul through virtuous actions and adherence to divine teachings.

item.title: Retribution of Actions
item.description: The surah teaches that human actions have direct consequences on the purity of the soul and divine retribution.

item.title: Lessons from Past Peoples
item.description: It uses historical examples to illustrate divine justice and how actions are rewarded or punished.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Layl (The Night) is the 92nd surah of the Quran, consisting of 21 verses. It is named after "al-layl," which means "the night." The surah contrasts night and day to illustrate the different paths that individuals can take in their spiritual lives. It addresses themes of wealth, poverty, and moral choices, emphasizing that life is a divine test. The surah describes the rewards for those who give generously and follow the right path, and the punishments for those who reject the truth and live in disbelief. It calls on believers to practice charity, piety, and consciousness of God, while highlighting divine justice in the retribution of human actions.
section.title: Contrasts between Day and Night

item.title: Contrasts between Day and Night
item.description: Verses 1-7: The surah begins with oaths by the night and the day, using these elements to symbolize contrasts between darkness and light. These contrasts illustrate the signs of divine creation and spiritual choices.

section.title: The Right Path and the Wrong Path

item.title: The Right Path and the Wrong Path
item.description: Verses 8-15: This section illustrates the choice between the right path and the wrong path, explaining how individuals can choose their spiritual and moral path, and the consequences of these choices on their destiny.

item.title: Rewards and Retributions
item.description: Verses 16-21: The surah describes the rewards for those who follow the right path and the punishments for those who reject faith and deviate from divine principles. It assures that actions have direct consequences.

item.title: Day-Night Contrasts
item.description: Utilizes contrasts between day and night to illustrate spiritual and moral choices. Night is associated with darkness and uncertainty, while day is related to clarity and guidance.

item.title: Choice between Virtue and Vice
item.description: Highlights the free will of individuals to choose between the right path, leading to success and divine satisfaction, and the wrong path, leading to perdition.

item.title: Rewards and Punishments
item.description: Assures that personal choices will have direct consequences, with rewards for believers who follow the right path and punishments for those who deviate from divine principles.

item.title: Divine Justice
item.description: Emphasizes that divine justice is inevitable. Each individual will be judged according to their actions and life choices, with appropriate consequences.

section.introduction: Surah Ad-Duḥā (The Morning) is the 93rd surah of the Quran, consisting of 11 verses. It is named after "ad-duḥā," which means "the morning" or "the light of the morning." The surah was revealed to comfort the Prophet Muhammad after a period of interrupted revelation. It begins with oaths by the morning light and the night when it settles, emphasizing the constancy and stability of divine creation. The surah mentions God's blessings and reminds the Prophet not to be discouraged. It highlights the importance of gratitude to God for His blessings and encourages generosity and benevolence towards others. It also assures that the Prophet's situation will improve, and his trials will be followed by success and divine blessings.
section.title: Divine Comfort and Support

item.title: Divine Comfort and Support
item.description: Verses 1-4: Oaths by the clear morning and the dark night, with assurance that God does not leave His Prophet alone. Difficult moments are followed by comfort and divine support.

item.title: Gratitude and God's Blessings
item.description: Verses 5-8: Reminder of the blessings granted by God to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). Encouragement to recognize and be thankful for these blessings despite challenges.

item.title: Instructions and Advice
item.description: Verses 9-11: Instructions on supporting orphans and those in need, with a call to compassion and social justice. Invitation to trust in God and move forward with faith and patience.

item.title: Divine Comfort
item.description: Assurance that God supports and guides His Prophet even during difficult times. Divine presence is constant, providing comfort and support.

item.title: Gratitude for Blessings
item.description: Encouragement to recognize and be thankful for divine blessings. Acknowledgment of God's benefits is essential despite trials.

item.title: Support for Others
item.description: Call to do good and support those in need, particularly orphans. Compassion and social justice are important values to practice.

item.title: Trust in God
item.description: Invitation to trust in God and move forward with faith and patience despite challenges. Trust in divine guidance is crucial for overcoming trials.

section.introduction: Surah Ash-Sharḥ (The Relief) is the 94th surah of the Quran, consisting of 8 verses. It is also known as "The Opening" or "The Expansion of the Chest." The surah was revealed to comfort and encourage the Prophet Muhammad during a difficult period, assuring him that God had expanded his heart to bear the prophetic mission. It describes divine blessings, emphasizing that every difficulty is followed by ease and relief. The surah calls for patience and perseverance in the face of trials, while highlighting the necessity of gratitude to God for His blessings. It also encourages the Prophet and believers to turn to God and seek His help in times of difficulty.
section.title: Comfort for the Prophet

item.title: Comfort for the Prophet
item.description: Verses 1-3: Promise of relief from the difficulties faced by Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). Assurance that times of hardship will be followed by relief and an opening of the heart.

item.title: Opening of the Heart
item.description: Verses 4-6: Expansion of the Prophet's heart as a divine blessing, enabling him to face challenges with patience and perseverance. Invitation to be patient and grateful for God's blessings.

item.title: Instructions and Advice
item.description: Verses 7-8: Encouragement to keep moving forward with determination despite obstacles. Promise that ease will follow difficulties, and reminder that God rewards patience and perseverance.

item.title: Divine Comfort
item.description: Promise of relief and opening of the heart after periods of difficulty. Assurance that difficulties are temporary and will be followed by comfort.

item.title: Patience and Gratitude
item.description: Invitation to be patient and grateful for divine blessings, even during difficult times.

item.title: Ease After Hardship
item.description: Assurance that difficulties are temporary and will be followed by moments of ease and relief. Ease will come after hardship.

item.title: Continue with Determination
item.description: Encouragement to advance with determination despite obstacles, trusting in the divine promise of relief and ease.

section.introduction: Surah At-Tīn (The Fig) is the 95th surah of the Quran, consisting of 8 verses. It is named after "at-tīn," meaning "the fig," which is mentioned at the beginning of the surah as a symbol of divine creation. The surah reflects on the creation of man and highlights the beauty and perfection of God's creation. It speaks to the value of humanity and the responsibility of each individual to lead a righteous and pious life. The surah emphasizes the concept of reward and punishment according to human actions, underscoring that man is created in the best form but is tested by his own deeds. It calls for reflection on divine creation and the need to follow the right path by recognizing God's signs and acting with integrity.
section.title: Divine Creation

item.title: Divine Creation
item.description: Verses 1-3: Reference to symbols of divine creation such as the fig tree, the olive tree, and Mount Sinai. Emphasis on the dignity of man as a divine creation, highlighting the grandeur of creation.

item.title: Morality and Responsibility
item.description: Verses 4-5: Emphasis on individual responsibility in the choice between good and evil. The capacity of man to deteriorate through bad actions is highlighted.

item.title: Reward and Punishment
item.description: Verses 6-8: Assurance that those who choose virtue and good deeds will be rewarded, while those who choose wicked and unjust actions will be punished. Emphasis on divine justice and fair judgment.

section.introduction: Surah Al-‘Alaq (The Clot) is the 96th surah of the Quran, consisting of 19 verses. It is notable for being the first surah revealed to the Prophet Muhammad. The surah begins with the divine command "Iqra" (Read), emphasizing the importance of reading, education, and knowledge. It describes the creation of man from a clinging substance, illustrating God's power and wisdom in creation. The surah highlights divine revelation as a source of guidance for humanity and reminds of the importance of submitting to God's will. It also addresses the behavior of those who oppose the truth and how God will judge them. The surah encourages recognizing divine blessings and practicing faith with humility and devotion.
section.title: Divine Creation

item.title: Divine Creation
item.description: Verses 1-3: Declaration of God as the Creator and mention of the creation of man from a clinging substance. God's grandeur as Creator is emphasized, and humanity's dependence on Him is highlighted. The term "Al-‘Alaq" refers to the state of the human embryo in the womb, emphasizing how man is formed and develops through divine will.

item.title: The Importance of Learning
item.description: Verses 4-5: Call to read and learn, highlighting that education is a means to draw closer to God and understand His greatness. God is described as the Creator and Teacher, and education is presented as essential in Islam.

item.title: Relationship with the Disbelievers
item.description: Verses 6-11: Warning against those who turn away from God and do not believe in His power. Description of opposition to divine revelation and how God deals with those who turn away from His message.

item.title: The Spiritual Aspect
item.description: Verses 1-11: Emphasis on the importance of spiritual connection with God, and invitation to reflect on creation and recognize divine greatness.

item.title: Divine Creation
item.description: Description of the creation of man from a fundamental substance and emphasis on God's grandeur as Creator.

item.title: Importance of Education
item.description: Call to learning and reading as means to draw closer to God and understand His greatness.

item.title: Opposition to Disbelievers
item.description: Warning against those who turn away from God and revelation. Emphasis on trust in God and remaining steadfast in faith.

item.title: Spiritual Aspect

section.introduction: Surah Al-Qadr (The Night of Decree) is the 97th surah of the Quran, consisting of 5 verses. It deals with Laylat al-Qadr, a particularly significant and blessed night during Ramadan when the Quran was first revealed. The surah describes the greatness of this night, emphasizing that it is better than a thousand months. It mentions that angels descend to earth during this night, bringing peace and blessings until dawn. The surah reminds of the importance of seeking this night for devotion and prayer, encouraging believers to increase their worship and seek forgiveness during this period. It underscores that Laylat al-Qadr is a time of immense divine mercy and guidance for believers.
section.title: Significance of Laylat al-Qadr

item.title: Significance of Laylat al-Qadr
item.description: Verses 1-3: Declaration of the greatness of the Night of Decree, which is better than a thousand months. This is the night when the Quran was first revealed to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). It is filled with blessings and peace, and angels descend to earth to deliver divine commands.

item.title: The Revelation of the Quran
item.description: Verses 4-5: Mention of the descent of angels and divine commands during this blessed night. The revelation of the Quran is highlighted as having a profound impact on the spiritual life of believers.

section.title: Importance of the Night of Decree

item.title: Importance of the Night of Decree
item.description: Verses 1-5: Invitation to seek this night during Ramadan, especially the odd nights of the last ten days. Highlighting spiritual rewards for those who engage in prayer and worship during this night.

item.title: Reflection on Divine Grandeur
item.description: Verses 1-5: Reminder of the greatness of the Night of Decree and God’s infinite mercy. Invitation to reflect on the significance and importance of the Quran as divine guidance for humanity.

item.title: Grandeur of Laylat al-Qadr
item.description: The night is better than a thousand months and is filled with blessings and peace.

item.title: Divine Revelation
item.description: The Night of Decree marks the revelation of the Quran, which is a divine guide for humanity.

item.title: Spiritual Importance
item.description: Believers are encouraged to seek this night and engage in prayer and worship to receive spiritual rewards.

item.title: Divine Reflection
item.description: The surah reminds of God’s greatness and the importance of revelation for spiritual guidance.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Bayyina (The Clear Proof) is the 98th surah of the Quran, consisting of 8 verses. It addresses the clear and evident revelation brought by Prophet Muhammad, which is the clear proof of the truth of Islam. The surah emphasizes that divine proofs are clear to those who believe and highlights the rewards for the pious believers and the consequences for the disbelievers. It describes the characteristics of sincere believers who follow God's path with devotion and perseverance, and condemns the disbelievers who reject the truth despite clear signs. The surah calls for sincere faith, obedience to God, and recognition of divine revelations as a source of guidance and truth.
section.title: Clear Proof

item.title: Clear Proof
item.description: Verses 1-3: Declaration that Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) brought a clear and explicit proof of divine truth through the Quran.

item.title: Believers and Disbelievers
item.description: Verses 4-6: Description of believers as those who accept and follow the revelation, and disbelievers as those who persist in their disbelief despite clear signs.

item.title: Rewards and Consequences
item.description: Verses 7-8: Promise of rewards for the believers and mention of punishment for the disbelievers.

item.title: Reflection on the Divine Message
item.description: Verses 1-8: Invitation to reflect on the clarity and certainty of the divine message. Importance of accepting the divine message to receive divine blessings.

item.title: Clear Proof

item.description: The surah describes the contrast between those who accept faith and those who reject it despite clear signs.

item.title: Reflection on the Message
item.description: The surah invites reflection on the clarity of the divine message and the importance of following the teachings of the Quran.

section.introduction: Surah Al-Zalzalah (The Earthquake) is the 99th surah of the Quran, consisting of 8 verses. It describes the catastrophic events of the Day of Judgment, highlighting a violent earthquake that shakes the earth. The surah mentions how the earth will reveal its secrets and how people's deeds will be exposed. It emphasizes that each individual will be judged according to their actions, whether good or bad. The surah calls for awareness of the reality of divine judgment and encourages believers to lead a just and pious life in preparation for the Day of Judgment. It reminds of the inevitable truth of divine retribution and the importance of personal responsibility.

item.title: Reward and Punishment
item.description: Individuals are judged and rewarded or punished based on their actions, emphasizing divine justice.

item.title: Awareness of Judgment
item.description: The surah calls for awareness of the reality of the Day of Judgment and encourages virtuous conduct.

section.introduction: Surah Al-‘Ādiyāt (The Courser) is the 100th surah of the Quran, consisting of 11 verses. It begins with an oath by the horses, the steeds that run with strength and power. The surah describes the characteristics of these horses, their movements, and their breath to illustrate the nature of human actions and how they are judged by God. It highlights human neglect of divine blessings and ingratitude despite clear signs from God. The surah reminds that human actions, whether good or bad, will be examined and judged by God. It calls on believers to recognize divine blessings and prepare for judgment by leading a righteous and grateful life.
section.title: Description of the Horses

item.title: Description of the Horses
item.description: Verses 1-5: Description of the powerful and swift horses, illustrating attachment to material possessions and the energy invested in these possessions.

item.title: Benefits of Earthly Life
item.description: The surah uses the image of horses laden with material benefits to draw an analogy with how people are consumed by their material desires.

item.title: Greed and Neglect of Faith
item.description: Verses 6-8: Critique of human greed and neglect of faith, emphasizing the importance of focusing on spiritual values rather than earthly wealth.

item.title: The Divine Judgment
